original: yon ni mthong ba'i chos la myong //
analyzed: yon ni mthong ba'i chos la myong //
translated: The result of giving is experienced in this life.

original: zhes bshad pa lta bu dang / de bzhin du sangs rgyas la mchod pa byas pas tshe 'di nyid la rnam par smin pa phyug po la sogs pa'i 'bras bu nyams su myong bar 'gyur ro zhes mdo sde las ji skad gsungs pa lta bu'o //
analyzed: zhes bshad pa lta bu dang / de bzhin du sangs rgyas la mchod pa byas pas tshe 'di nyid la rnam par smin pa phyug po la sogs pa'i 'bras bu nyams su myong bar 'gyur ro zhes mdo sde las ji skad gsungs pa lta bu'o //
translated: And likewise, by making offerings to the Buddha, you experience the result in this very life, such as becoming wealthy.

analyzed: 'on te de bzhin gshegs pa yon tan dpag tu med pa dang ldan pa'i phyir /

analyzed: mchod par bya bar rigs kyi sems can rnams la ni de lta ma yin no zhe na /
translated: but it is not right to do so for sentient beings.”

original: de bzhin gshegs pa'i yon tan rnams kyi nang nas gang la brten te sangs rgyas kyi chos skye ba zhes bya ba'i yon tan ni sems can rnams la'ang yod pa'i phyir /

translated: But since among the good qualities of the Tathāgata there is a good quality called “the arising of the qualities of a buddha,” and since sentient beings also have that,🔽they are worthy of offerings.

original: des na mchod pa'i gnas yin pas yon tan rgya mtsho zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te /
analyzed: des na mchod pa'i gnas yin pas yon tan rgya mtsho zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te /

original: ji ltar de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa la sogs pa la brten nas sangs rgyas kyi chos skye ba bzhin du sems can rnams la brten nas kyang skye bar 'gyur ro zhes bya ba'i tha tshig go //
analyzed: ji ltar de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa la sogs pa la brten nas sangs rgyas kyi chos skye ba bzhin du sems can rnams la brten nas kyang skye bar 'gyur ro zhes bya ba'i tha tshig go //
translated: Just as the Buddha qualities arise in dependence on making offerings to the Tathagatas and so on, so they arise in dependence on sentient beings.

original: da ni thams cad la shin tu phan 'dogs par mdzad pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa de rnams la drin lan ldon pa'i thabs dam pa yin pa'i phyir yang sems can rnams mgu bar bya'o zhes bstan pa'i phyir /

translated: Now, in order to demonstrate that sentient beings should be pleased because they are the supreme means of repaying the kindness of those Tathagatas who act to benefit all,

original: gzhan yang zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
analyzed: gzhan yang zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: he says, “Moreover,” and so on.

original: 'on te ji tsam du bdag la phan 'dogs par mdzad ce na /
analyzed: 'on te ji tsam du bdag la phan 'dogs par mdzad ce na /
translated: But how do they benefit you?

original: gang gi phyir zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
analyzed: gang gi phyir zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: He says, “Because,” and so on.

translated: Now, in order to exhort himself to strive for the welfare of sentient beings, the Master says, “For a while,” and so on.

original: 'on te gang dag bde bas thub pa rnams dgyes par 'gyur zhing /
analyzed: 'on te gang dag bde bas thub pa rnams dgyes par 'gyur zhing /
translated: But if you ask, “Who are those by pleasing whom the Buddhas are pleased,

analyzed: gang la gnod pa byas na thub pa'i dbang po rnams mi dgyes 'byung bar 'gyur ba yin zhe na /
translated: and by harming whom they are harmed? ”

original: de dag ces bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
analyzed: de dag ces bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: [The answer is:] “those” and so on.

original: ji ltar zhe na /
analyzed: ji ltar zhe na /
translated: How is that?

analyzed: sdig pa bshags shing phyin chad mi byed par bsdam par bya ba'i phyir /
translated: Now, in order to confess the evil done by harming sentient beings in the past, and to restrain oneself from doing it again in the future, so that the Tathāgatas will not be displeased,

analyzed: de bas bdag gis zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: [the text] says “Therefore, I confess” and so on.

original: 'gums kyang mi bsngo zhes bya ba ni /
analyzed: 'gums kyang mi bsngo zhes bya ba ni /
translated: “Even if they kill me” means

analyzed: sems can de dag gis bdag gi srog bcad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa rnams mi dgyes pas mi bsngo ste /

analyzed: 'o na ji ltar zhe na /
translated: But how is that?

original: bdag gi srog gcod pa ni bla'i /
analyzed: bdag gi srog gcod pa ni bla'i /
translated: It would be better if they took my life.

original: mi dgyes pa ni mi bgyi'o zhes bya ba'i don to //
analyzed: mi dgyes pa ni mi bgyi'o zhes bya ba'i don to //
translated: The meaning is that one should not displease them.

original: 'on te de ci'i phyir zhe na /

translated: But why?

analyzed: sems can rnams mgu bar 'gyur ba de ltar bya zhe na /
translated: If one asks, “How should one act in order to please sentient beings?”

original: de nyid ces bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
analyzed: de nyid ces bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: he says, “That very . . .” and so on.

analyzed: dper na rgyal po zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: he says, “For example, a king . . .” and so on.

analyzed: 'on te sems can rnams mgu bar byas na phan yon ci zhig yod nas de ltar bya zhe na /
translated: But if one asks, “What is the benefit of acting in that way to please sentient beings?”

original: sems can mgu las zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
analyzed: sems can mgu las zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: he says, “From the satisfaction of sentient beings . . .” and so on.

analyzed: bstan bcos kyi ming gi don ni snga ma bzhin no //

analyzed: dge ba'i chos yongs su rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir le'u drug pa gsungs te /

analyzed: brtson 'grus brtsams pa'i phan yon dang ma brtsams pa'i nyes dmigs bstan pa'i sgo nas /

original: brtson 'grus brtsam par bya ba bstan pa'i phyir /
analyzed: brtson 'grus brtsam par bya ba bstan pa'i phyir /
translated: in order to teach the undertaking of striving,

analyzed: da ni brtson 'grus kyi le'u las rnam par gzhag pa bstan pa'i phyir /
translated: Now, in order to teach the presentation from the chapter on striving,

analyzed: sgyid lug ces bya ba la sogs pa smos te /
translated: he says, “The power of laziness…”

analyzed: de la rtsa ba dang pos ni mi mthun pa'i phyogs gzhom pa bstan to //
translated: There, the first root teaches the destruction of the opposing side.

analyzed: rtsa ba gnyis pas ni brtson 'grus kyi ngo bo nyid bstan to //
translated: The second root teaches the nature of striving.

analyzed: gsum pas ni gang gi don du brtsams pa bstan to //

original: bzhi pas ni gang la brtsams pa bstan to //
analyzed: bzhi pas ni gang la brtsams pa bstan to //

original: da ni de'i rgyas par bshad pa bstan pa'i phyir /
analyzed: da ni de'i rgyas par bshad pa bstan pa'i phyir /
translated: Now, in order to teach its extensive explanation,🔽he says, “There, in terms of the power of laziness…”

original: de la sgyid lug pa'i stobs gzhom pa'i dbang du byas nas /
analyzed: de la sgyid lug pa'i stobs gzhom pa'i dbang du byas nas /
translated: In terms of the power of laziness,

original: bdag gi zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
analyzed: bdag gi zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: he says, “My laziness…”

original: de ci'i phyir zhe na /
analyzed: de ci'i phyir zhe na /
translated: Why is that?

original: 'di ltar zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
analyzed: 'di ltar zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: Thus, etc.

original: 'on te byang chub thob par bya ba la ni shin tu gces pa'i rkang lag la sogs pa nyid kyang btab @328b dgos pa'i phyir de ni bdag gis mi phod de 'jigs so zhe na /
analyzed: 'on te byang chub thob par bya ba la ni shin tu gces pa'i rkang lag la sogs pa nyid kyang btab @328b dgos pa'i phyir de ni bdag gis mi phod de 'jigs so zhe na /
translated: But if you say, “I am afraid to give away my very own cherished limbs and so on in order to attain enlightenment,”

analyzed: gces dang zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: the verse says, “What’s cherished and what’s not, etc.”

analyzed: gces dang mi gces pa ji lta ba bzhin du mi shes pas gces par bya ba ma yin pa la gces su gzung ba'i phyir 'jigs par zad pas /

analyzed: 'jigs par mi bya'o zhes bya ba'i don to //

translated: Moreover, at times when you are born in the lower realms due to nonvirtuous karma, you repeatedly give away your body and limbs and so on for no purpose.

analyzed: byang chub chen po bsgrub pa'i don du gtong ba'i sdug bsngal gyis te 'jigs zhes gsungs pa'i phyir /

analyzed: bskal pa bye ba zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so //
translated: The ten million eons and so on are mentioned.

translated: Therefore, in order to remove the great suffering of cyclic existence, one should not be afraid of the suffering of giving and so on in the context of achieving enlightenment.

original: de bzod cing dang du blang bar bya'i zhes bstan par bya ba'i phyir /
analyzed: de bzod cing dang du blang bar bya'i zhes bstan par bya ba'i phyir /
translated: In order to teach that one should endure and accept that, it is said:

analyzed: bdag gi byang chub ces bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: My enlightenment and so on.

original: 'on te 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal chen po bsal bar bya ba'i phyir /
analyzed: 'on te 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal chen po bsal bar bya ba'i phyir /
translated: But in order to remove the great suffering of cyclic existence,

translated: But at that time, is meat, etc. not also to be given?

analyzed: ji ltar na cho ga 'jam po yin zhe na /
translated: How is it that the rite is gentle?

original: tshod ma la sogs pa gsungs te /
analyzed: tshod ma la sogs pa gsungs te /
translated: Vegetables, etc. are mentioned.

analyzed: bsdus pa'i don ni las dang po pa'i skabs su sha la sogs pa gtang bar bya ba ma yin gyi /

translated: It is merely the giving of vegetables, etc. and since that is not delightful, and since at the time when one enters the stage of pure universal responsibility, one becomes very familiar with giving, it is not difficult. Thus, the meaning is that the rite is very gentle.

original: 'on te goms par 'gyur ba de lta yin na yang tsha ba la sogs pa'i sdug bsngal dang yan lag la sogs pa ma tshang ba'i rgyus sems la mi dga' ba skye ba'i phyir cho ga shin tu 'jam po ma yin no zhe na /

translated: But if, although one becomes familiar with that, the rite is not very gentle because mental unhappiness arises due to the cause of the suffering of heat, etc. and the incompleteness of limbs, etc.?

original: sdig pa spang phyir zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
analyzed: sdig pa spang phyir zhes bya ba la sogs pa smos so //
translated: The verse says, “To abandon evil deeds, etc.”

original: lus la gnod pa 'byung ba'i rgyu @329a * //
analyzed: lus la gnod pa 'byung ba'i rgyu @329a * //
translated: The cause of harm to the body is

analyzed: sdig pa spang ba'i phyir dang / sems la gnod pa byed pa'i log par rtog pa'i gnyen po rang bzhin med pa nyid du mkhas pa'i phyir /

analyzed: lus bde ba yin zhing lus la sogs pa gtong ba de nyid byang chub chen po'i rgyu nyid yin par mkhas pa'i phyir /

analyzed: bdag gis sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa yongs su rdzogs par bya snyam du sems dga' ba skye bar 'gyur bas /

analyzed: de lta bas na cho ga shin tu 'jam po nyid yin pa'i phyir /
translated: Thus, because the rite is very gentle,

translated: even though one abides in cyclic existence for the sake of sentient beings for three measureless eons and performs all the difficult deeds, one should not be born and become weary.

analyzed: le'u dang por ji skad bshad pa'i tshul du byang chub kyi sems shin tu 'jam po nyid yin pa'i phyir /
